text: I think we've made a lot of progress but
it's nowhere near where I wanted to be
because by 2020 I want to get to the
point when it is equal between men and
women on our radio channels on our
television programs as well I think
we've made some progress and I think
over the last three four years or last
three years anyway
60% of the new hires we've done for all
promotions we've done have been women
that's good you see that only 10 o'clock
news you you feel that on the Today
programme which now can be sometimes
just presented by women you see it on
Strictly or indeed on the new Doctor Who
but I think we've got much more to do
there and I am determined to get it
right when I first came back to the BBC
I wanted to get a another woman to
prevent the Today program we did it took
a couple of months and I wanted to get
our local radio stations who at that
point 14 percent of their breakfast
shows were presented by women the rest
were done by men I said I want to get to
half and half in two years and we got
there as well I'm a great believer in
action behind the principles you stand
for so that's the thing I really want to
achieve the next two 20 years but there
are people who will look at this list
and say actually you might have made
progress in your time as
director-general but the evidence is
emphatically clear only a third of the
people here list are female the top page
stars are dominated very much by men and
although individual circumstances vary
and you have to look at rotary and all
that sort of thing there are several
shows where men and women seem to do
similar jobs and the men are paid much
much more if they're actually quite a
clear signal here which is if all the
talk about gender equality the BBC is
way behind where it should be there
where we're making big strides but I
just want to stress I'm not complacent
we have a lot to do and I want us to be
an exemplar not just a media companies
but to the whole of the UK about how to
handle us but if you look at the gender
pay gap which the average for the whole
of the UK is just over 18 percent we're
at 10 percent so already were in a
better place than the average but I'm
not complacent about that there's a lot
to do and I'm determinate we're going to
do that
